node.text: Take a sneak peek into the noisy cavern of the largest particle detector in the world @atlasexperiment with Theo Alexopoulos and @chit_chet_ and look at the experiment’s newest addition - the New Small Wheels 🔵

node.title: Live from the ATLAS Cavern and Small Wheels Lab

node.text:
With the Proton Synchrotron and its Booster accelerating protons to high energies again, the physics season can start at the ISOLDE radioactive ion beam facility. 💥💻 

During several #upgradingLHC activities, two new target stations have been installed at ISOLDE and protons are back for studying physics.

#PhotoOfTheWeek by @leauickque and @chit_chet_
🎵: Your Gain

node.title: Physics season at CERN’s ISOLDE facility

node.text:
CERN lays first stone of Science Gateway 🪨 

Scheduled to open in 2023, CERN is increasing its capacity to welcome visitors of all ages, from near and far and extending its educational portfolio with a view to increasingly inspiring future generations towards science and research. 

What are you most excited to see inside #CERNScienceGateway? 😀

🎥 by Titouan Robin Chapuis, @chit_chet_

node.text:
Happy 50th birthday hadron colliders! 🙌

#ThrowbackThursday #TBT 

50 years ago, CERN scientists collided particles in the first hadron collider ever built. On 27 January 1971, CERN’s Intersecting Storage Rings (ISR) produced the world’s first proton–proton collisions.
Physicists had planned this machine in the 1960s, based on the idea that smashing two particle beams head on would give much higher energies than colliding a single beam of particles with a fixed target. 

This first hadron collider helped change the views of members of the physics community, who doubted the usefulness of hadron colliders. By the time it shut down in 1984, it had produced many important results, including indications that protons contain smaller constituents, ultimately identified as quarks and gluons.

node.text:
Since the Standard Model leaves many questions unanswered, physicists have proposed theories that go beyond it, some of which explain the nature of dark matter. Among such theories are those suggesting the existence of axions or axion-like particles. These theories need to be tested, and many experiments have been set up around the world to look for these particles, including at CERN. 

One antimatter experiment at CERN, BASE, has now, for the first time, turned the tools developed to detect single antiprotons, the #antimatter equivalent of a proton, to the search for #darkmatter! 😍

node.text:
#Doyouknow why matter dominates over antimatter in the universe? 😲

This situation makes a detailed study of antimatter of immense significance not just for physics but also for cosmology. 🌌

25 years ago, CERN announced producing the first atoms of antimatter. This handful of antihydrogen atoms were created on the Low Energy Antiproton Ring (LEAR), a machine used to accumulate and store antiprotons. The international team from @forschungszentrum_juelich, @uni_fau, @universeinthelab, and @unigenova led by Walter Oelert succeeded for the first time in linking an antiproton and a positron, but for a very short time. ⏱🔍

#ThrowbackThursday #TBT 

🎞 The experiment had only 48 hours of beam time during the very last months of the LEAR machine and its success opened the path to a new antimatter machine, the Antiproton Decelerator (AD), that hosts several experiments studying #antimatter today. 💯

node.title: First Atoms of Antimatter at CERN

node.text:
Steven Weinberg (1933-2021) 💫

One of the greatest theoretical physicists of all times passed away last week . Steven Weinberg is most known for the unified theory of weak and electromagnetic forces that earned him the @nobelprize_org in 1979. 

In this #ThrowbackThursday, Steven Weinberg had just got back from Stockholm to collect his prize, and later gave the seminar “The rise and fall of baryon number" at CERN. His audience remained fascinated during the whole conference: it is not everyday that you meet someone who has radically changed the way we look at the universe! 🌟

node.text:
Guess what this is 🔎 

These cylindrical tubes covered in aluminum are part of CERN’s neutron time-of-flight facility’s third generation spallation target. They belong to the nitrogen gas cooling system of this machine designed to produce a neutron beam.
 
The n_TOF facility studies neutron-nucleus interactions. It contributes to the measurement of nuclear data but also produces data used in astrophysics and hadron therapy. 
 
The new lead-based and nitrogen cooled n_TOF spallation target that you see in this photo has received its first proton beam after #upgradingLHC! 🌟

Photo by CERN on July 23, 2021.
A scientist is analyzing samples of water.

node.text:
#ThrowbackThursday to water sampling in 1975 👩‍🔬
 
The first photo shows a scientist analysing water samples from Lake Geneva and from the Lyon river. In the second photo, she is collecting samples from the river, near CERN’s North Experimental Hall. 🔬
 
CERN manages its environmental footprint responsibly by collecting and analysing many water samples every year. CERN recently published its first public environmental report, which also includes innovations made at CERN that are being adapted for environmental protection. 

#CERNImpact

A scientist is collecting samples of water.
Photo by CERN on July 21, 2021. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
After SPS.. the beam has reached n_TOF! 
 
CERN’s accelerator complex is slowly coming to life as we go #upgradingLHC. This week, we have started sending the proton beam to the n_TOF facility – a CERN facility exploring neutron-nucleus interactions. 
 
This #PhotoOfTheWeek shows you the cooling station of the third generation n_TOF spallation target. 
 
#Didyouknow that this is the first time we have produced a neutron spallation target in pure lead cooled by nitrogen gas and moderated by light water and borated water? 💦⚙️
 
Swipe to see the cooling station of the third generation n_TOF 👀🆒

node.text:
Guess what this is ☀️

This is a photomultiplier tube, a device that can detect single photons. It is part of protoDUNE, an experimental programme testing technologies for the Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment (DUNE). This international experiment is currently being constructed in the United States and will study a beam of neutrinos produced at @fermilab in Illinois and sent all the way to @sanfordlab in South Dakota.
 
#DidYouKnow that the protoDUNE detector is a cube representing the size of a three-story house? And guess what: the real size of DUNE’s detectors will be 20 times larger! 📦 

📸 by @julienordan

node.text: Take a sneak peek into the noisy cavern of the largest particle detector in the world @atlasexperiment with Theo Alexopoulos and @chit_chet_ and look at the experiment’s newest addition - the New Small Wheels 🔵

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by CERN on July 15, 2021 tagging @nasa, and @nasaastronauts. May be an image of 5 people, people standing and airplane.

node.text:
#ThrowbackThursday to 4 June 1969 when one of the @nasaastronauts astro Russel L. Schweickart visited CERN 👨‍🚀⠀
⠀
He gave a lecture about his flight on @NASA #Apollo9 and the future of space exploration. ⠀
⠀
The visit of such a fascinating guest generated a lot of enthusiasm: at a time when TV was not yet a widespread medium, the Main Auditorium technicians had to deal with 22 closed circuit TV extensions during his lecture! This technical achievement allowed about 1250 people to listen to the conference.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN in LHC :: Large Hadron Collider. May be an image of indoor.

node.text:
Blue or white, choose your favourite 😉⠀
⠀
#PhotoOfTheWeek by @max.brice ⠀
⠀
These colours represent the different superconducting magnets of the Large Hadron Collider. The blue dipole magnets bend the particle beams so that they can circle inside the 27-km tunnel, whereas the white quadruple magnets focus the beam.

node.text:
🎙️Today CERN is launching a new podcast series on artificial intelligence

The #CERNSparks podcast series explores #AI, the first edition of the Sparks! Serendipity Forum — where 50 leading thinkers will discuss the future of intelligence here at CERN in September.📍 

From coders to neuroscientists, and philosophers to psychologists, The #CERNSparks Podcast collides pairs of the world's leading experts on #AI 🤖 — don't miss out!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by CERN on July 09, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing and indoor.

node.text:
Can you guess what they are looking at? 🤔

This image shows an interconnection between LHC dipole magnets being opened for an endoscope inspection. These maintenance tasks help to ensure the smooth running of the complex giant that is the LHC. 

In December 2018, the LHC’s second run came to an end and a long shutdown began, for  maintenance tasks as well as upgrades. In March 2021, the symbolic key to the machine was handed back to the operating team and now the accelerator complex is beginning to restart. 

📸 by @max.brice
